The winners play a 120-board today and tomorrow to decide the U.S.A.-2 team for the Shanghai world championships, which begin at the end of September.
The Deutsch team led by 11 imps after Board 73. The diagramed deal was No. 74.

The auction given was produced by Meckstroth (North) and Rodwell. It gives an insight into the scientific methods they employ when having slam potential. South's opening bid showed 14-16 points. He sensibly added one point for his excellent five-card club suit.

Two diamonds was a transfer, promising five or more hearts with any point-count, and two no-trump artificially announced four-plus clubs with at least game-forcing values. Three clubs was an inquiry denying three-card heart support. Four no-trump showed 2-5-2-4 distribution with slam-invitational values.
South, although he had a subminimum in high-card terms, had five great trumps, another ace and a potentially useful heart queen. He had no qualms about jumping to six clubs.

Rodwell won West's spade-king lead on the board with the ace, unblocked the king and queen of diamonds, played a club to his queen and cashed the diamond ace, discarding dummy's remaining spade. South ruffed a spade on the board, took dummy's heart ace and played a heart to his queen and West's king. At this point declarer claimed. The defense could not stop him from ruffing his last spade in the dummy and drawing trumps.

At the other table Kranyak (South) opened one club, and Deutsch (North) responded one heart. South rebid one no-trump, showing 12-14 points, and North continued with two diamonds, an artificial inquiry. South bid two no-trump, denying three hearts, and North raised to three no-trump.

In the other match both South players bid three clubs over two diamonds, which made reaching six clubs much easier. But Deutsch could have continued with three clubs over two no-trump, which would surely also have resulted in the slam's being reached.
After a spade lead Kranyak took his 10 top tricks.
Plus 1,370 and minus 630 gave the Nickell team 12 imps and the lead.

In Thursday's column Jill Meyers opened two hearts with a 1-5-6-1 nine-count. This was incorrectly described as a weak two-bid. It showed at least five hearts, five or more cards in any other suit and some 5-10 high-card points, a Polish two-bit. Jill Levin's two-no-trump response asked for the second suit, and Meyers's four-diamond rebid showed 5-6 and a maximum.
With a weak two-bid in either major, Meyers would have opened two diamonds.
